newsitem.title: JAPAN: Dlr inches up vs yen but gains limited in Tokyo.
newsitem.headline: Dlr inches up vs yen but gains limited in Tokyo.

text.p: The dollar inched up against the yen by Tokyo midday Thursday on short-covering by interbank traders, but its gains were limited as market participants remained reluctant to take up heavy positions ahead of a forthcoming meeting of Group of Seven (G7) officials.
Dealers said exporters were keen to sell dollars around 126.50 yen, keeping the dollar's topside heavy.
There was talk that life insurers may have been behind late-morning dollar purchases, but most dealers said it was more short-covering by short-term players than anything else.
"Traders do not have a major reason to buy the greenback today," a trust bank dealer said, adding that the outcome of G7 meeting still has potential to push the greenback down.

Dealers said the greenback is likely to fall should the G7 meeting come up with a stronger-than-expected warning against recent currency movements. "A possible fall in dollars after the G7 meeting depends on whether the outcome is stronger than the one in the last G7 meeting," one bank dealer said.

A city bank dealer said: "The dollar could fall sharply if the G7 meeting signals possible joint (dollar-selling) intervention. But otherwise the dollar will be supported near 125 yen with solid bids from institutional investors, even if it falls after the meeting."

Dealers said exporters, seen eager to sell dollars before Japan's "Golden Week" holiday next week, were expected to kick in to sell the greenback near 126.50 yen. A trust bank dealer said U.S. funds bought back British pounds for dollars after sterling eased against the dollar overnight, which briefly weighed on dollar/mark rates.

Sterling fell in overseas trading on Wednesday due to latest British polls that indicated May 1 general elections could be tighter-than-expected. In addition, optimism that Europe's proposed single currency stands a good chance of launching as scheduled in January 1999 weighed on the British pound, while Britain is not slated to join the euro group.
Sterling stood near $1.6280/90 at midday, up from $1.6228/38 at New York close.
In trade against mark, the greenback remained mostly directionless by midday.
